data.title: Add button to resource viewer to open unsupported resource in external program
data.body:
**Bug**
Can't view cat gifs in VSCode resource viewer. We only display images that are < 1mb :(
    
**Fix**
 Add a more specific error message for large images and adds button to try opening the file in an external program

data.title: [Feature Request] Preview for SVG files
data.body:
It would be nice to be able to open an SVG as an image from its code as the preview of the markdown files.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/686196/23923928/00a5e4fc-0909-11e7-9f05-820b37f51e7f.png)

And see changes in real times when the editor is splitted.

data.title: [Feature Request] Support in VS Installer
data.body: With Visual Studio 2017 we got new Visual Studio Installer application where we can install and manage all VS 2017 installations. It would be great if we could install and manage even Visual Studio Code from that app.

data.title: Create IContext type, dynamic `getValue`
data.body:
This PR changes `context: any` to `context: IContext` with the following interface:

```ts
export interface IContext {
	getValue<T>(key: string): T;
}
```

As I use the `Menu` infrastructure, I discovered that every time I call `getActions()` on it, a context evaluation happened. This envolves calling [`contextMatchRules`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/5cbb1b0d8e7659f1538286d2d3c1ef4eba4221ed/src/vs/platform/contextkey/browser/contextKeyService.ts#L171) which creates an object containing the whole context at that given point in time.

I found this while implementing multi-select in the SCM viewlet, which happens to use Menus extensively, where creating all these contexts all the time flared up the CPU profiler quite a lot:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/23921704/eaf23182-08ff-11e7-88c4-707c1899a39f.png)

In this profile, I'm multi selecting rows in the SCM viewlet, which makes them refresh, which makes them re-render. Re-rendering these causes `getActions` to get called, creating all those contexts, which happens to be taking up most of the CPU time. Each of those is a single click, blocking the UI thread for ~250ms.

By creating an `IContext` type, I introduce a `getValue` method, which simply avoids creating static contexts all the time. Plus it gets rid of a few `any` types.

After the PR, the profile looks like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/23922096/5ef16246-0901-11e7-9e9d-c31ab28d9d96.png)

Each of the multi-selections takes now ~50ms. Further optimization needs to happen on the list/renderer side.

---

Another alternative which I have explored is to use ES6 Proxy objects for contexts which would let us have dynamic _getters_. This is cool üèÑ but barely usable in browsers in which the editor has to be compatible. We can still do it for Electron, although it would just be unnecessary voodoo, imo.

---

I realise that making the context values accessible via a `getValue` method might not be ideal, or even against the whole point, because we might want to keep the context static. But we seem to be paying a high price for that choice. This PR aims to open up that conversation, as it is my opinion that we need to improve performance in this area.

data.title: Can't bind Ctrl + / and Ctrl + ; to different commands on a Brazilian Keyboard.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:00:46.854Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.16.0-4-amd64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|empty-indent|DmitryDorofeev|0.2.0|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.1|
|crane|HvyIndustries|0.3.3|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.5.1|
|php-formatter|Sophisticode|0.2.4|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.3.0|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.0.33|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|file-icons|file-icons|1.0.3|
|vscode-sort|henriiik|0.2.5|
|phpcs|ikappas|0.7.0|
|indentation-level-movement|kaiwood|1.1.1|
|vscode-colorize|kamikillerto|0.3.2|
|vue|liuji-jim|0.1.5|
|camelcasenavigation|maptz|0.2.3|
|code-beautifier|michelemelluso|1.6.2|
|vscode-duplicate|mrmlnc|1.1.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.6.0|
|php-docblocker|neilbrayfield|0.2.0|
|vetur|octref|0.5.1|
|advanced-new-file|patbenatar|0.4.0|
|gotolastedit|plrenaudin|0.2.1|
|gitlink|qezhu|0.2.0|
|laravel-artisan|ryannaddy|0.0.6|
|ci-snippets|secato|0.0.1|
|php-ci|small|0.1.3|
|guides|spywhere|0.7.0|
|autoimport|steoates|1.2.2|
|autoend|thousandtyone|1.0.16|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit `keybindings.json`
2. Click `Define Keybinding (Ctrl + K Ctrl + K)`
3. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>/</kbd> on a Brazilian Keyboard

Expected:
Keys showed should be <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>/</kbd>

Result:
Keys showed is <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>;</kbd>

Details:
I want to set different shortcuts for those combinations of keys, but I can't. For VS Code, <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>;</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>/</kbd> are the same damn thing. By default, pressing these keys, VS Code toggle comments on a line. I want <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>;</kbd> to put a semicolon at the end of the line. And <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>/</kbd> to toggle comments.

data.title: AddConfigurations does not respect `{` on the same line as `[`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

I can't quite figure out exactly what seems to cause this, but a common factor seems to be when the launch.json file is hand-edited as mentioned in the repro steps.  Once VS code gets into a state where the Node.js specific debug config options are displayed, I can't figure out how to get them back - the only way I have found is to delete the launch.json file and start over which obviously isn't ideal.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In VS Code, clone the following node.js project: https://github.com/scotch-io/node-todo
2. Open the above project, click the debug button in the left hand pane, and then in the debug configuration drop-down menu, choose to "Add configuration" (note that at this point, you shouldn't have any configurations created).
3. From the configuration popup menu, notice that you are presented with a list of common Node.js configurations - select the "Node.JS: Launch Program" configuration.
4. In the first configuration option, change the "program" value to "${workspaceRoot}/server.js" - don't change anything else in the file and then save.
6. Open the debug configuration drop-down menu again and choose "Add configuration".

This time, when the configuration popup menu is displayed, all of the Node.js configuration options are missing.  Refer to the first attached screen shot shows the actual list; the second screenshot shows what should be displayed instead.

![actual](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10600161/23920024/15274ca0-08c7-11e7-9739-f99c971ccd44.png)
![expected](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10600161/23920023/150e10b4-08c7-11e7-8609-3aec8e643e2a.png)

data.title: Long strings are cutoff when hovering over local value while debugging
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

This issue likely can be repro'ed with other types of projects, but I ran into this when working with node.js where you hover over a value during debugging that contains a large string.  

For example, node.js's internal modules have methods that take the contents of an entire javascript file as a string parameter in order to compile it (such as VM.js's runInThisContext method) - if you attempt to hover over this parameter to see its value while debugging, you aren't able to see all of the javascript because it is cutoff and there isn't any ability to scroll within the window to see all of the javascript.  This can be painful when trying to debug.

Below are basic steps to repro the issue - but keep in mind, that the real scenario when I've hit this is when debugging through node.js internal modules where javascript is passed around as a string parameter.

1. Create a node.js project
2. Store a string as a var and place a break point on the variable (the string should be very long, such as the contents of a multiline js file)
3. When you hit the breakpoint, hover over the var to see it's value

Notice that the popup that shows the value of the string doesn't have scrollbars - also, if the contents of the string are long enough, the text will be cut off so that you can't see the entire contents of the string value.

Here is a screenshot that also shows the problem - note that when I hover over the "code" parameter.  The popup window doesn't have anyway to scroll through the entire contents of the "code" parameter and it's cutoff so that I can't view all of the parameter's value.
![cutoff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10600161/23923229/d656e992-08d3-11e7-9413-839050922d44.png)

data.title: Git clone F1 command error when no folder/project is open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch VS Code - ensure that NO folder\project is open in VS Code (when a project is opened, the command works as expected)
2. Press the F1 key
3. In the commands text box, type "git: clone" - when the command becomes selected, hit enter
4. Expected: Next you should be prompted for the git project url to clone
    Actual: An error occurs saying "command 'git.clone' not found

data.title: Login like in Visual Studio IDE to preserve keybinding and other settings
Support for JSDoc parameter properties
data.body:
VSCode does not appear to show intellisense when documenting a parameter's properties.

See http://usejsdoc.org/tags-param.html

> If a parameter is expected to have a specific property, you can document that property by providing an additional @param tag. For example, if an employee parameter is expected to have name and department properties, you can document it as follows:

> Documenting a parameter's properties

```
/**
 * Assign the project to an employee.
 * @param {Object} employee - The employee who is responsible for the project.
 * @param {string} employee.name - The name of the employee.
 * @param {string} employee.department - The employee's department.
 */
function Project(employee) {
    // ...
};
```

(note that I changed the above example to not use a prototype as that just confuses things)

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 v1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Create the above code
2.  Type `Project({ na`
3.  Intellisense should understand that you are typing the `name` property of the `employee` object, but it does not.

data.title: Integrated terminal (cygwin64 bash) not rendering color escape codes on php output
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.14393 Build 14393

Using cygwin64 bash.exe as integrated terminal like so:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20228401/23908400/d601ec74-08cb-11e7-8d4d-ded8b696e5f8.png)

Standard color prompt works just fine:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20228401/23908475/0ee2a48e-08cc-11e7-8e49-ae7a05aaae01.png)

**However executing a PHP script, color escape codes are not interpreted properly, resulting in garbled output. Specifically, running Laravel's artisan command**:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20228401/23908588/5baf62c0-08cc-11e7-8b89-f31f161b2530.png)

This same command works as expected in mintty:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20228401/23908820/f18c15cc-08cc-11e7-9eeb-8b25e7da43c8.png)

Am i doing anything wrong or is this a bug?

Love the program though!

data.title: Bad experience when TypeScript server crashes
data.body:
Quite often I find the TypeScript has crashed. VS Code gives me no indication of this‚ÄîI have to look at the server output myself using the panel provided. Tooltips show as "Loading‚Ä¶" indefinitely.

Ideally:

- We would warn the user the server has crashed, perhaps prompting them to restart the server. It may also be useful to show the loading status of the server, so the user knows when TS is and isn't ready to use. I often find myself hitting "go to definition" multiple times as I wait for it to finish loading.
- We would provide a way to restart the server https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22335

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921609/23907793/18718b70-08ca-11e7-8a0c-8570579cf435.png)

Not sure why the server crashes, this time round I got this error (omitted stack trace):

```
Error processing request. symbol.getFlags is not a function
TypeError: symbol.getFlags is not a function
```

data.title: Icon for *.scss file not showing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (dd197f19ddad6f8fa960c5f330fb7182c2321de3, 2017-03-13T07:11:52.101Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.3.0|
|sass-indented|robinbentley|1.3.0|
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `scss` file.
2. `scss` icon of `vscode-icons` not showing. Expected icon to be shown (https://github.com/vscode-icons/vscode-icons/blob/master/icons/file_type_scss.svg)

Issue is noticeable only on `Code-Insiders` due to this change (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/96bbe8100efa66d25e18ada2b1cbee499d7cf736)
Probably this [line](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/scss/package.json#L12) of code is to blame.

More info @ https://github.com/vscode-icons/vscode-icons/issues/808

data.title: Problems in formatting of lines (support of comments)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Begin write the comment (in [phpDocumentor](https://phpdoc.org) style).
```
	/**
	 * @var string[] of supported intervals
	 */
```

2. Press enter and line will be begin from tab + space.
```
	/**
	 * @var string[] of supported intervals
	 */
	 private $whySpaceBefore;
```

I am expected to see something like this:
```
	/**
	 * @var string[] of supported intervals
	 */
	private $whySpaceBefore; // with out space before
```

data.title: Build Error
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: git latest (How to contribute)
- OS Version: Windows 2008 R2

Steps to Reproduce:

.\scripts\npm install
```

116198 error Windows_NT 6.1.7601
116199 error argv "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe" "C:\\Users\\MYUSER\\AppData\\Roaming\\npm\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "install"
116200 error node v7.7.2
116201 error npm  v4.2.0
116202 error code ELIFECYCLE
116203 error errno 1
116204 error vscode-ripgrep@0.0.7 postinstall: `node ./src/postinstall.js`
116204 error Exit status 1
116205 error Failed at the vscode-ripgrep@0.0.7 postinstall script 'node ./src/postinstall.js'.
116205 error Make sure you have the latest version of node.js and npm installed.
116205 error If you do, this is most likely a problem with the vscode-ripgrep package,
116205 error not with npm itself.
116205 error Tell the author that this fails on your system:
116205 error     node ./src/postinstall.js
116205 error You can get information on how to open an issue for this project with:
116205 error     npm bugs vscode-ripgrep
116205 error Or if that isn't available, you can get their info via:
116205 error     npm owner ls vscode-ripgrep
116205 error There is likely additional logging output above.
116206 verbose exit [ 1, true ]

```

Any idea how to fix this postinstall error?

data.title: Checks integrated terminal output for more types of relative paths
data.body:
Integrated terminal output is now checked for relative paths of the format ```src/app/file.ts```, that is, relative paths without a leading ```./```

These types of relative paths are checked to make sure the file they are referring to actually exists.

Some tests were added to verify the paths are properly formatted in order to check for the file.

Note: This was not tested in a Windows environment

Fixes #22528

data.title: Turning off word-based suggestions isn't enough for comments
data.body:
I set `editor.wordBasedSuggestions: false` in my user-level settings, and even restarted vscode, but if I open a `*.js` JavaScript file and type the following:

        // If

Still, vscode pops up some kind of suggestions about the JavaScript keyword `if`, even though I'm trying to write simple English in my comment.  Is there any way to really, fully disable all suggestions for comments?

(Originally posted in an unrelated issue, #17426)
